introduction.p: We have already encountered some examples of polynomial functions. Linear functions, f (x) = ax + b and quadratic functions f (x) = ax^2 + bx + c are special cases of polynomial functions. In general, we make the following definition.

assemblage.title: Polynomial Function
assemblage.p: A polynomial functionpolynomial function has the form f (x) = a_n x^n + a_{n-1}x^{n-1} + a_{n-2}x^{n-2} + \cdots + a_2x^2 + a_1x + a_0 where a_0, a_1, a_2, \ldots, a_n are constants and a_n \ne 0. The coefficient a_n of the highest power term is called the lead coefficientlead coefficient.

introduction.p:
Some examples of polynomials are
f(x)\amp= 6x^3 - 4x^2 + x - 2 \amp g(x) \amp= 9x^5 - 2
p(x) \amp = x^4 + x^2 + 1 \amp q(x) \amp= 2x^{10} - x^7 + 3x^6 + 5x^3 + 3x

Each of the polynomials above is written in descending powersdescending powers, which means that the highest-degree term comes first, and the degrees of the terms decrease from largest to smallest. Sometimes it is useful to write a polynomial in ascending powersascending powers, so that the degrees of the terms increase. For example, the polynomial f(x) above would be written as
f(x) = -2 + x - 4x^2 + 6x^3
in ascending powers.

subsection.title: Products of Polynomials
subsection.p: When we multiply two or more polynomials together, we get another polynomial of higher degree. (See Algebra Skills Refresher A.7 for the definition of degree.)

In a, we multiplied a polynomial of degree 1 by a polynomial of degree 3, and the product was a polynomial of degree 4. In b, the product of three first degree polynomials is a third-degree polynomial.

assemblage.title: Degree of a Product
assemblage.p: The degree of a product of nonzero polynomials is the sum of the degrees of the factors. That is,
If P(x) has degree m and Q(x) has degree n, then their product P(x)Q(x) has degree n + m.

example.p:
Let P(x) = 5x^4 - 2x^3 + 6x^2 - x + 2, and Q(x) = 3x^3 - 4x^2 + 5x + 3.
What is the degree of their product? What is the coefficient of the lead term?
Find the coefficient of the x^3-term of the product.

li.p: The degree of P is 4, and the degree of Q is 3, so the degree of their product is 4 + 3 = 7. The only degree 7 term of the product is (5x^4)(3x^3) = 15x^7, which has coefficient 15.

In the product, each term of P(x) is multiplied by each term of Q(x). We get degree 3 terms by multiplying together terms of degree 0 and 3, or 1 and 2. For these polynomials, the possible combinations are:

P(x) Q(x) Product
2 3x^3 6x^3
-2x^3 3 -6x^3
-x -4x^2 4x^3
6x^2 5x 30x^3
The sum of the third-degree terms of the product is 34x^3, with coefficient 34.

statement.p: Find the coefficient of the fourth-degree term of the product of f(x) = 2x^6 + 2x^4 - x^3 + 5x^2 + 1 and g(x) = x^5 - 3x^4 + 2x^3 + x^2 - 4x - 2.

subsection.title: Factoring Cubics
subsection.p:
Another pair of products is useful for factoring cubic polynomials. In the Homework problems, you will be asked to verify the following products:
(x + y)(x^2 - xy + y^2) \amp= x^3 + y^3
(x - y)(x^2 + xy + y^2) \amp= x^3 - y^3
Viewing these products from right to left, we have the following special factorizations for the sum and difference of two cubes.
When we recognize a polynomial as a sum or difference of two perfect cubes, we then identify the two cubed expressions and apply the formula.

li.p:
This polynomial is a sum of two cubes. The cubed expressions are 2a, because (2a)^3 = 8a^3, and b. Use formula as a pattern, replacing x with \alert{2a}, and y with \blert{b}.
x^3 + y^3 \amp= (x + y) (x^2 - xy + y^2)
(\alert{2a})3 + \blert{b}3 \amp= (\alert{2a} + \blert{b}) ((\alert{2a})^2 - (\alert{2a})\blert{b} + \blert{b}^2) \amp\amp\text{Simplify.}
\amp= (2a + b) (4a^2 - 2ab + b^2)

This polynomial is a difference of two cubes. The cubed expressions are 1, because 1^3 = 1, and 3h^2, because (3h^2)^3 = 27h^6. Use formula above as a pattern, replacing x by \alert{1}, and y by \blert{3h^2}:
x^3 - y^3 \amp= (x - y) (x^2 + xy + y^2)
\alert{1}^3 - (\blert{3h^2})^3 \amp= (\alert{1} - \blert{3h^2})(\alert{1}^2 + \alert{1}(\blert{3h^2}) + (\blert{3h^2})^2)\amp\amp\text{Simplify.}
\amp= (1 - 3h^2)(1 + 3h^2 + 9 h^4)

subsection.title: Modeling with Polynomials
subsection.p: Polynomials model many variable relationships, including volume and surface area.

example.p:
A closed box has a square base of length and width x inches and a height of 8 inches, as shown in . box with height 8 inches with both length and width of x inches
Write a polynomial function S(x) that gives the surface area of the box in terms of the dimensions of the base.
What is the surface area of a box of length and width 18 inches?

li.p:
The surface area of a box is the sum of the areas of its six faces,
S = 2lh + 2wh + 2lw
Substituting x for l and w, and 8 for h gives us
S(x) = 2(8)x + 2(8)x + 2x^2 = 2x^2 + 32x

We evaluate the polynomial for x = 18 to find
S(18) = 2(18)^2 + 32(18) = 1224 \text{ square inches}

statement.p:
An empty reflecting pool is 3 feet deep. It is 8 feet longer than it is wide, as illustrated in . rectangular hole 3 ft deep, x feet wide, x+8 ft long
Write a polynomial function S(x) that gives the surface area of the empty pool.
Write a polynomial function V(x) for the volume of the pool.

subsection.p: Cubic polynomials are often used in economics to model cost functions. The cost of producing x items is an increasing function of x, but its rate of increase is usually not constant.

example.p:
Pegasus Printing, Ltd. is launching a new magazine. The cost of printing x thousand copies is given by
C(x) = x^3 - 24x^2 + 195x + 250
What are the fixed costs, that is, the costs incurred before any copies are printed?
Graph the cost function in the window below and describe the graph.
\text{Xmin} \amp = 0 \amp\amp \text{Xmax} = 20
\text{Ymin} \amp = 0 \amp\amp \text{Ymax} = 1500
How many copies can be printed for $1200?
What does the concavity of the graph tell you about the cost function?

li.p: Fixed costs are given by C(0) = 250, or \$250. The fixed costs include expenses like utility bills that must be paid even if no magazines are produced.
The graph is shown in a. It is increasing from a vertical intercept of 250. The graph is concave down for x \lt 8 approximately, and concave up for x\gt 8. GC graphs of a cubic cost function

We must solve the equation x^3 - 24x^2 + 195x + 250 = 1200 We will solve the equation graphically, as shown in b. Graph y = 1200 along with the cost function, and use the intersect command to find the intersection point of the graphs, (15.319, 1200). C(x) = 1200 when x is about 15.319, so 15,319 copies can be printed for \$1200.

Although the cost is always increasing, it increases very slowly from about x = 5 to about x = 11. The flattening of the graph in this interval is a result of economy of scale: By buying supplies in bulk and using time efficiently, the cost per magazine can be minimized. However, if the production level is too large, costs begin to rise rapidly again.

subsection.p: In c, we solved a cubic equation graphically. There is a cubic formula, analogous to the quadratic formula, that allows us to solve cubic equations algebraically, but it is complicated and not often used. See the Projects for Chapter 7 if you would like to know more about the cubic formula.
Cubic polynomials are also used to model smooth curves connecting given points. Such a curve is called a cubic spline.
